newsitem.title: UK: Euro Crude Outlook - Margins, thin loadings support.
newsitem.headline: Euro Crude Outlook - Margins, thin loadings support.

text.p: European crudes have shrugged off the effect of resumed Iraqi exports and, supported by leaner than anticipated September North Sea loading programmes, should remain strong this week, traders said.
Thirsty U.S. demand for gasoline that has boosted margins on both sides of the Atlantic will continue to encourage high refinery throughputs, buoying crude demand.
Cargoes of gasoline have been tempted transatlantic, stripping bare an already tight European market for light end product, traders said.

Balancing the surging margins has been a tight U.S. arbitrage for crude which looks set to continue as sustained demand for vessels to load Kirkuk Blend from Turkey's Ceyhan port pushes freight rates sky high.
But with the eight major North Sea export streams loading 280,000 barrels per day (bpd) less in September than in August supply will be balanced to tight.
Some 4.14 million bpd were due to load next month, with Brent down 1.5 million barrels and Forties over two million lower.
Major maintenance at Gullfaks has hit output, as have problems at Snorre which forced the delay of five Statfjord cargoes from August to September.
Last week's cloud on the horizon was the prospect of 30 million barrels of Iraqi crude depressing underlying prices. But that threat has largely dissipated.
"The Iraqi oil is being absorbed," said one dealer. "I know several buyers of Iraq were really thirsty as they were waiting for more than a month."
The first Iraqi barrels to be exported since late May were loaded last Thursday at Ceyhan bound for the U.S.

"Everyone waited for Iraq to come out," said a trader with a major grade seller. "Although it hit sour when it came it didn't hit sweets and they're better because of U.S. gasoline and I think that demand will continue."
Last week wet Brent was supported by swaps-related buying by one Wall Street trader, who bought four cargoes in the September -5 to -9 range on Thursday and Friday.
Contracts for difference were sold off cheaply at the end of the week as the trader repositioned himself to reoffer barrels without a home, traders said.
Although those wet Brents were expected to weigh on the physical market the underlying demand for sweet crude should keep the Dated discount to September Brent within the 10- to 20- cent range.
Other North Sea grades will enjoy good premiums, with values on Draugen, Ekofisk, and Oseberg all firming late last week.

Other Norwegian grades, particularly the offshore loaders with fixed shipping costs, look even better placed as freight rates surge. Gullfaks and Statfjord both gained 10 cents a barrel and were set to stay buoyant.
While the North Sea has survived the return of Iraq unscathed the effect on Urals markets has been as predicted.
